Journal.Title: Environmental science and pollution research international

Article.ArticleTitle: Decadal changes in surface ozone at the tropical station Thiruvananthapuram (8.542° N, 76.858° E), India: effects of anthropogenic activities and meteorological variability.

AbstractText: This paper presents the first observational results from an Indian station on the long-term changes in surface ozone (O<sub>3</sub>)-a major environmental pollutant and green house gas-over a period of about 40 years. It is based on the in situ measurements carried out during 1973-1975, 1983-1985, 1997-1998 and 2004-2014 at the tropical coastal station, Thiruvananthapuram. From 1973 to 1997, surface O<sub>3</sub> shows a slow increase of ~ 0.1 ppb year<sup>-1</sup> and a faster increase of 0.4 ppb year<sup>-1</sup> afterwards till 2009 after which it showed a levelling off till 2012 followed by a minor decrease. The highest rate of increase is observed during 2005 to 2009 (2 ppb year<sup>-1</sup>), and the overall increase from 1973 to 2012 is ~ 10 ppb. The increase in day time O<sub>3</sub> (peak O<sub>3</sub>) is estimated as 0.42 ppb year<sup>-1</sup> during 1997-2012 and 2.93 ppb year<sup>-1</sup> during 2006-2012. Interestingly, the long-term trend in O<sub>3</sub> showed seasonal dependence which is more pronounced during O<sub>3</sub> peaking seasons (winter/summer). The observed trends were analysed in the light of the changes in NO<sub>2</sub>, a major outcome of anthropogenic activities and methane which has both natural and anthropogenic sources and also meteorological parameters. Surface O<sub>3</sub> and NO <sub>x</sub> exhibited positive association, but with varying rate of increase of O<sub>3</sub> for NO <sub>x</sub> < 4 and > 4 ppb. Methane, a precursor of O<sub>3</sub> also showed increase in tune with O<sub>3</sub>. Unlike many other high-latitude locations, meteorology plays a significant role in the long-term trends in O<sub>3</sub> at this tropical site with water vapour abundance and strong solar irradiance which favour photochemistry. A comparison with the corresponding changes in the satellite-retrieved tropospheric column O<sub>3</sub> (TCO) also showed an increase of 0.03 DU year<sup>-1</sup> during 1996-2005 which enhanced to 0.12 DU year<sup>-1</sup> after 2005. Both surface O<sub>3</sub> and satellite-retrieved TCO were positively correlated with daily maximum temperature, increasing at the rate of 1.54 ppb °C<sup>-1</sup> and 1.9 DU °C<sup>-1</sup>, respectively, on yearly basis. Surface O<sub>3</sub> is found to be negatively correlated with water vapour content (ρ<sub>v</sub>) at this tropical site, but at higher levels of ρ<sub>v</sub>, O<sub>3</sub> shows a positive trend.
